trans-unit.source: ms.ContentId: 347fa279-d588-4094-90ec-8c2fc241f5b6 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker
trans-unit.target: ms.ContentId: 347fa279-d588-4094-90ec-8c2fc241f5b6 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker

trans-unit.source: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker
trans-unit.target: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker

trans-unit.source: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing windows Server Containers with Docker.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing windows Server Containers with Docker.

trans-unit.source: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using Docker.
trans-unit.target: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using Docker.

trans-unit.source: Have questions?
trans-unit.target: Have questions?

trans-unit.source: Ask them on the <linkText>Windows Containers forum</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Ask them on the <linkText>Windows Containers forum</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Note: Windows Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.
trans-unit.target: Note: Windows Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.

trans-unit.source: To create containers with PowerShell, see <linkText>Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create containers with PowerShell, see <linkText>Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html> If you want to know more, <linkText>read the FAQ</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html> If you want to know more, <linkText>read the FAQ</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.
trans-unit.target: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Container Feature.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Container Feature.

trans-unit.source: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.
trans-unit.target: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.

trans-unit.source: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.
trans-unit.target: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.

trans-unit.source: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides: <linkText>Container Setup in Azure</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Container Setup in Hyper-V</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides: <linkText>Container Setup in Azure</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Container Setup in Hyper-V</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Basic Container Management with Docker
trans-unit.target: Basic Container Management with Docker

trans-unit.source: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with Docker.
trans-unit.target: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with Docker.

trans-unit.source: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Start a PowerShell session by typing powershell.
trans-unit.target: Start a PowerShell session by typing powershell.

trans-unit.source: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from C:\directory> to PS C:\directory>.
trans-unit.target: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from C:\directory> to PS C:\directory>.

trans-unit.source: This quick start will be focused on Docker commands however some steps such as managing firewall rules and copying files will be run with PowerShell commands.
trans-unit.target: This quick start will be focused on Docker commands however some steps such as managing firewall rules and copying files will be run with PowerShell commands.

trans-unit.source: Work through this walkthrough from a PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Work through this walkthrough from a PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using ipconfig and take note of this address for later use.
trans-unit.target: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using ipconfig and take note of this address for later use.

trans-unit.source: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using ipconfig you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using ipconfig you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create a New Container
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create a New Container

trans-unit.source: Before creating a Windows Server Container with Docker you will need the name or ID of an exsisitng Windows Server Container image.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a Windows Server Container with Docker you will need the name or ID of an exsisitng Windows Server Container image.

trans-unit.source: To see all images loaded on the container host use the docker images command.
trans-unit.target: To see all images loaded on the container host use the docker images command.

trans-unit.source: Now, use docker run To create a new Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: Now, use docker run To create a new Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: This command as seen below will instruct the Docker daemon to create a new container named ‘dockerdemo’ from the image ‘windowsservercore’ and open an interactive (-it) console session (cmd) with the container.
trans-unit.target: This command as seen below will instruct the Docker daemon to create a new container named ‘dockerdemo’ from the image ‘windowsservercore’ and open an interactive (-it) console session (cmd) with the container.

trans-unit.source: When the command completes you will be working in a console session on the container.
trans-unit.target: When the command completes you will be working in a console session on the container.

trans-unit.source: Working in a container is almost identical to working with Windows installed on a virtual or physical machine.
trans-unit.target: Working in a container is almost identical to working with Windows installed on a virtual or physical machine.

trans-unit.source: You can run commands such as ipconfig to return the IP address of the container, mkdir to create a new directory, or powershell to start a PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: You can run commands such as ipconfig to return the IP address of the container, mkdir to create a new directory, or powershell to start a PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.
trans-unit.target: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.

trans-unit.source: You can read the contents of the file to ensure the command completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: You can read the contents of the file to ensure the command completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the IP address contained in the text file matches that of the container.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the IP address contained in the text file matches that of the container.

trans-unit.source: Now that the container has been modified, run the following to stop the console session placing you back in the console session of the container host.
trans-unit.target: Now that the container has been modified, run the following to stop the console session placing you back in the console session of the container host.

trans-unit.source: Finally to see a list of containers on the container host use the docker ps –a command.
trans-unit.target: Finally to see a list of containers on the container host use the docker ps –a command.

trans-unit.source: Notice from the output that a container named 'dockerdemo' has been created.
trans-unit.target: Notice from the output that a container named 'dockerdemo' has been created.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image

trans-unit.source: An image can now be made from this container.
trans-unit.target: An image can now be made from this container.

trans-unit.source: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.
trans-unit.target: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.

trans-unit.source: To create a new image run the following.
trans-unit.target: To create a new image run the following.

trans-unit.source: This command instructs the Docker engine to create a new image named 'newcontainerimage' that will include all changes made to the 'deckerdemo' container.
trans-unit.target: This command instructs the Docker engine to create a new image named 'newcontainerimage' that will include all changes made to the 'deckerdemo' container.

trans-unit.source: To see all images on the host, run docker images.
trans-unit.target: To see all images on the host, run docker images.

trans-unit.source: Notice that a new image has been created with the name 'newcontainerimage'.
trans-unit.target: Notice that a new image has been created with the name 'newcontainerimage'.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a custom container image, deploy a new container named 'newcontainer' from 'newcontainerimage' and open an interactive shell session with the container.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a custom container image, deploy a new container named 'newcontainer' from 'newcontainerimage' and open an interactive shell session with the container.

trans-unit.source: Take a look at the c:\ drive of this new container and notice that the ipconfig.txt file is present.
trans-unit.target: Take a look at the c:\ drive of this new container and notice that the ipconfig.txt file is present.

trans-unit.source: Exit the newly created container to return to the container hosts console session.
trans-unit.target: Exit the newly created container to return to the container hosts console session.

trans-unit.source: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.
trans-unit.target: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.

trans-unit.source: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.
trans-unit.target: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.

trans-unit.source: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.
trans-unit.target: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Images
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Images

trans-unit.source: To remove a container after it is no longer needed use the docker rm command.
trans-unit.target: To remove a container after it is no longer needed use the docker rm command.

trans-unit.source: The following command will remove the container name 'newcontainer'.
trans-unit.target: The following command will remove the container name 'newcontainer'.

trans-unit.source: To remove container images when they are no longer needed use the docker rmi command.
trans-unit.target: To remove container images when they are no longer needed use the docker rmi command.

trans-unit.source: You cannot remove an image if it is referenced by an existing container.
trans-unit.target: You cannot remove an image if it is referenced by an existing container.

trans-unit.source: The following command removes the container image named 'newcontainerimage'.
trans-unit.target: The following command removes the container image named 'newcontainerimage'.

trans-unit.source: Host a Web Server in a Container
trans-unit.target: Host a Web Server in a Container

trans-unit.source: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.
trans-unit.target: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.

trans-unit.source: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Download Web Server Software
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Download Web Server Software

trans-unit.source: Before creating a container image the web server software will need to be downloaded and staged on the container host.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a container image the web server software will need to be downloaded and staged on the container host.

trans-unit.source: We will be using the nginx for Windows software for this example.
trans-unit.target: We will be using the nginx for Windows software for this example.

trans-unit.source: Note that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.
trans-unit.target: Note that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.

trans-unit.source: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.
trans-unit.target: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command on the container host to create the directory structure that will be used for this example.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command on the container host to create the directory structure that will be used for this example.

trans-unit.source: Run this command on the container host to download the nginx software to 'c:\nginx-1.9.3.zip'.
trans-unit.target: Run this command on the container host to download the nginx software to 'c:\nginx-1.9.3.zip'.

trans-unit.source: Finally the following command will extract the nginx software to 'C:\build\nginx\source'.
trans-unit.target: Finally the following command will extract the nginx software to 'C:\build\nginx\source'.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Create Web Server Image
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Create Web Server Image

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, you manually created, updated and captured a container image.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, you manually created, updated and captured a container image.

trans-unit.source: This example will demonstrate an automated method for creating container images using a Dockerfile.
trans-unit.target: This example will demonstrate an automated method for creating container images using a Dockerfile.

trans-unit.source: Dockerfiles contain instructions that the Docker engine uses to build and modify a container, and then commit the container to a container image.
trans-unit.target: Dockerfiles contain instructions that the Docker engine uses to build and modify a container, and then commit the container to a container image.

trans-unit.source: For more information on dockerfiles, see <linkText>Dockerfile reference</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on dockerfiles, see <linkText>Dockerfile reference</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to create an empty dockerfile.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to create an empty dockerfile.

trans-unit.source: Open the dockerfile with notepad.
trans-unit.target: Open the dockerfile with notepad.

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the following text into notepad, save the file and close notepad.
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the following text into notepad, save the file and close notepad.

trans-unit.source: At this point the dockerfile will be in 'c:\build\nginx' and the nginx software extracted to 'c:\build\nginx\source'.
trans-unit.target: At this point the dockerfile will be in 'c:\build\nginx' and the nginx software extracted to 'c:\build\nginx\source'.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to build the web server container image based on the instructions in the dockerfile.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to build the web server container image based on the instructions in the dockerfile.

trans-unit.source: To do this, run the following command on the container host.
trans-unit.target: To do this, run the following command on the container host.

trans-unit.source: This command instructs the docker engine to use the dockerfile located at C:\build\nginx to create an image named 'nginx_windows'.
trans-unit.target: This command instructs the docker engine to use the dockerfile located at C:\build\nginx to create an image named 'nginx_windows'.

trans-unit.source: The output will look similar to this:
trans-unit.target: The output will look similar to this:

trans-unit.source: When completed, take a look at the images on the host using the docker images command.
trans-unit.target: When completed, take a look at the images on the host using the docker images command.

trans-unit.source: You should see a new image named 'nginx_windows'.
trans-unit.target: You should see a new image named 'nginx_windows'.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 – Configure Networking for Container Application
trans-unit.target: Step 3 – Configure Networking for Container Application

trans-unit.source: Because you will be hosting a website inside of a container a few networking related configurations need to be made.
trans-unit.target: Because you will be hosting a website inside of a container a few networking related configurations need to be made.

trans-unit.source: First a firewall rule needs to be created on the container host that will allow access to the website.
trans-unit.target: First a firewall rule needs to be created on the container host that will allow access to the website.

trans-unit.source: In this example we will be accessing the site through port 80.
trans-unit.target: In this example we will be accessing the site through port 80.

trans-unit.source: Run the following script to create this firewall rule.
trans-unit.target: Run the following script to create this firewall rule.

trans-unit.source: This script can be copied into the VM.
trans-unit.target: This script can be copied into the VM.

trans-unit.source: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.
trans-unit.target: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article: <linkText>Set up Azure VM Endpoints</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article: <linkText>Set up Azure VM Endpoints</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginx_windows' container run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginx_windows' container run the following command.

trans-unit.source: This will create a new container named 'nginxcontainer' and start an console session on the container.
trans-unit.target: This will create a new container named 'nginxcontainer' and start an console session on the container.

trans-unit.source: The –p 80:80 portion of this command creates a port mapping between port 80 on the host to port 80 on the container.
trans-unit.target: The –p 80:80 portion of this command creates a port mapping between port 80 on the host to port 80 on the container.

trans-unit.source: Once working inside the container, the nginx web server can be started and web content staged.
trans-unit.target: Once working inside the container, the nginx web server can be started and web content staged.

trans-unit.source: To start the nginx web server, change to the nginx installation directory.
trans-unit.target: To start the nginx web server, change to the nginx installation directory.

trans-unit.source: Start the nginx web server.
trans-unit.target: Start the nginx web server.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 – Access the Container Hosted Website
trans-unit.target: Step 5 – Access the Container Hosted Website

trans-unit.source: With the web server container created, you can now checkout the application hosted in the container.
trans-unit.target: With the web server container created, you can now checkout the application hosted in the container.

trans-unit.source: To do so, open up a browser on different machine and enter http://containerhost-ipaddress.
trans-unit.target: To do so, open up a browser on different machine and enter http://containerhost-ipaddress.

trans-unit.source: Notice here that you will be browsing to the IP Address of the Container Host and not the container itself.
trans-unit.target: Notice here that you will be browsing to the IP Address of the Container Host and not the container itself.

trans-unit.source: If you are working from an Azure Virtual Machine this will be the public IP address or Cloud Service name.
trans-unit.target: If you are working from an Azure Virtual Machine this will be the public IP address or Cloud Service name.

trans-unit.source: If everything has been correctly configured, you will see the nginx welcome page.
trans-unit.target: If everything has been correctly configured, you will see the nginx welcome page.

trans-unit.source: At this point, feel free to update the website.
trans-unit.target: At this point, feel free to update the website.

trans-unit.source: Copy in your own sample website, or run the following command in the container to replace the nginx welcome page with a ‘Hello World’ web page.
trans-unit.target: Copy in your own sample website, or run the following command in the container to replace the nginx welcome page with a ‘Hello World’ web page.

trans-unit.source: After the website has been updated, navigate back to http://containerhost-ipaddress.
trans-unit.target: After the website has been updated, navigate back to http://containerhost-ipaddress.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you would like to change the Docker Daemon settings (such as to change the port it listens to, to connect to a container remotely), you will need to edit the file "C:\ProgramData\docker\runDockerDaemon.cmd" in the container, and then you will need to restart the service with PowerShell, using Restart-Service docker.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you would like to change the Docker Daemon settings (such as to change the port it listens to, to connect to a container remotely), you will need to edit the file "C:\ProgramData\docker\runDockerDaemon.cmd" in the container, and then you will need to restart the service with PowerShell, using Restart-Service docker.

trans-unit.source: Video Walkthrough
trans-unit.target: Video Walkthrough

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you have containers set up and an introduction to the tools, go build your own containerized apps.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have containers set up and an introduction to the tools, go build your own containerized apps.

trans-unit.source: Remember, this is a preview there are bugs and we have a lot of work in progress.
trans-unit.target: Remember, this is a preview there are bugs and we have a lot of work in progress.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>This page</linkText><title></title> contains many of our known issues.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>This page</linkText><title></title> contains many of our known issues.

trans-unit.source: Be aware that there are some known Docker commands that <linkText>don't work</linkText><title></title> and some that only <linkText>partially work</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Be aware that there are some known Docker commands that <linkText>don't work</linkText><title></title> and some that only <linkText>partially work</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: We are also monitoring the <linkText>forums</linkText><title></title> very closely.
trans-unit.target: We are also monitoring the <linkText>forums</linkText><title></title> very closely.

trans-unit.source: There are also pre-made samples on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: There are also pre-made samples on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
